question: Question_01_(d)
sols:
Simple substitution does not work in this problem, so we will need to
integrate by parts. Let $\displaystyle u=\ln{x}$ and
$dv=\frac{dx}{x^2}=x^{-2}dx$. Then $du=\frac{dx}{x}$ and
$v=-x^{-1}=-\frac{1}{x}$. Thus,

$\int \frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\int \left ( -\frac{1}{x} \right ) \left ( \frac{dx}{x} \right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}+\int \left (\frac{dx}{x^2}\right )=-\frac{\ln{x}}{x}-\frac{1}{x}.$

Evaluating the definite integral then gives

$\int_{1}^{e}\frac{\ln{x}}{x^2}dx=\left ( -\frac{\ln{e}}{e}-\frac{1}{e} \right )- \left ( -\frac{\ln{1}}{1}-\frac{1}{1}
\right )= \left(-\frac{2}{e} \right )- \left( 0-1 \right )=-\frac{2}{e}+1.$

Therefore, the correct answer is (i).
